question: How is the United Way of Jamaica (UWJ) mobilizing resources through the Farmer's Rehabilitation Fund (FRF) to support farmers in the parishes of Clarendon, St Elizabeth, and Manchester, and what specific resources are being provided?
retrieved_answer: The United Way of Jamaica (UWJ) launched a Farmer's Rehabilitation Fund (FRF) with the aim of raising up to 20 million to provide immediate and long-term support to affected farming communities [2]. The UWJ aims to mobilize resources and provide financial support to farmers, specifically in the parishes of Clarendon, St Elizabeth, and Manchester, who were more severely impacted by Hurricane Beryl [2]. Seprod and Musson Foundations committed to donating 2 million to the rehabilitation fund [3]. The UWJ urges private and public organizations to collaborate to strengthen its efforts to provide effective assistance through the FRF initiative [4]. The FRF will facilitate access to critical resources including seeds, equipment, and financial aid to help farmers restore their livelihood [2][4].

"The Farmer's Rehabilitation Fund will facilitate access to critical resources including seeds, equipment, and financial aid to help farmers restore their livelihood. "What I am indicating here is that we have an aggressive timeline and it is therefore important that everyone comes on board to ensure that they can support this timeline.

"I have been out there since Tuesday and farmers are there, and yes, they want to get back to their farming, but there is no roof and that is also of importance to them. I felt helpless, because as the Ministry of Agriculture we cannot say anything about rebuilding houses, but we have to partner with all agencies within Government to ensure the well-being of the farming population and their relatives is taken care of," said Pryce.Chairperson at Seprod and Musson Foundations, Melanie Subratie, while describing the importance of farmers to food distributors across Jamaica, announced a commitment to donating 2 million to the rehabilitation fund. question: How is the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) utilizing its Special Fund for Emergency and Rehabilitation Activities (SFERA) to support the agricultural sector in Jamaica, and what specific actions have been taken to address the damage caused by Hurricane Beryl?
retrieved_answer:
The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) utilizes its Special Fund for Emergency and Rehabilitation Activities (SFERA) to mobilize technical assistance and support its coordination and response capacities in affected countries [1][3]. This includes the recruitment and rapid deployment of staff, field missions, logistics, partnerships, resource mobilization, and technical assistance activities [1][3].

To address the damage caused by Hurricane Beryl, which has severely affected agriculture and threatened food security and livelihoods [2], FAO has taken several specific actions:
*   FAO is deployed in the Caribbean areas affected by Hurricane Beryl to advance rapid needs assessment and prepare proposals to restore production and livelihoods [2].
*   FAO supports damage and needs assessment using drones and satellite remote sensing [2]. This information includes ground-level data collection through surveys and key informant interviews, which will guide response and recovery planning [2].
*   Agriculture in Jamaica has suffered damage, with preliminary assessments indicating several crops have been affected [2].
*   Reported damages include loss of fishing capacity, such as damage to vessels, support infrastructure, and fishing equipment, as well as damage to crops and livestock [2].
*   FAO is also working with the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UN-OCHA) on a response plan that includes identified needs, highlighting those of producers and fishermen [3].
*   Mario Lubetkin, FAO Assistant Director-General and Regional Representative for Latin America and the Caribbean, expressed FAO's commitment to Caribbean countries and reiterated support for mobilizing international cooperation for the response and recovery of agricultural, livestock, and fisheries production in the affected countries [1][3].

question: How is the REACH (Relief Emergency Assistance and Community Help) programme structured to ensure the equitable distribution of food and essential supplies in the most affected areas of Jamaica?

The REACH (Relief Emergency Assistance and Community Help) programme includes the distribution of food and essential supplies as one of its main elements [1]. The government is coordinating the continued distribution of food, water, medical sundries, and other essentials to citizens in the most affected areas [1].

To ensure equitable distribution, the Prime Minister stated that the process for determining who is assisted must be "absolutely transparent" to prevent favoritism [2]. He is developing a system that integrates past experiences and technology to properly identify "the needy beneficiary and not the greedy person" [2]. The REACH (Relief Emergency Assistance and Community Help) programme is structured to ensure the equitable distribution of food and essential supplies through a transparent and non-partisan process [2][3]. The Ministry of Labour and Social Security has been handing out care packages [1], which contain enough food for a family of four for four days [1][2]. The government coordinates the continued distribution of food, water, medical sundries, and other essentials [1]. An initial allocation of $5 million was provided for welfare activities, including food distribution [1][7], and an additional $4 million is allocated to all 63 constituencies to assist in the recovery effort [2].

The criteria used to determine the allocation of resources to the most affected areas in Jamaica involve a transparent assessment process [2][3]. This assessment is conducted by the Office of Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management (ODPEM), utilities, and public infrastructure [3]. Based on this assessment, constituencies are informed if they are categorized as "severely impacted" [3]. Support is provided to communities where virtually the entire housing stock has been destroyed [3], and assistance is directed to areas where the damage is greatest, such as Rocky Point and Portland Cottage on the south coast of Jamaica [3]. The process aims to properly identify the needy beneficiary [2].

question: What specific types of infrastructure in Jamaica were most affected by Hurricane Beryl, and what are the current priorities for restoration according to the reports?
retrieved_answer:
Hurricane Beryl caused extensive damage to utility poles and downed powerlines across parishes in Jamaica [1][2][4]. Other significantly affected infrastructure includes telecommunications, electricity, road, water, and roofing [1][2][4]. The storm also caused significant damage to shelters, health infrastructure, and housing [3][10]. Additionally, agriculture and other livelihoods such as fishing were impacted [3][8].

According to the reports, current priorities for restoration involve authorities steadily working to restore services such as telecommunications, electricity, road, and water [1][2][4], aiming to restore a semblance of normality to communities [1][2][4]. Authorities are also working to finish restoring basic services, including water, power, and health services [10].

The NEOC was activated at Level 3 ahead of the hurricane's impact and has been scaled down to Level 1 as assessments are being undertaken. question: How has the agricultural sector in Jamaica been impacted by Hurricane Beryl, and what steps are being taken to address these impacts?

The Prime Minister issued the Disaster Risk Management Enforcement Measures Order 2024, declaring Jamaica a disaster area [2][6]. The Government has formally acknowledged and accepted the offer of support from the United Nations (UN) [7]. The UN Resident Coordinator (RC) activated the United Nations Emergency Technical Team (UNETT) and reassured the Government of Jamaica of the UN's readiness to support [2][6]. The Office for Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management (ODPEM) and other government agencies started rapid needs assessments [6]. UNICEF participated in joint assessments organized by ODPEM on July 8th and 10th [7]. Humanitarians, including teams from OCHA and UN Disaster Assessment and Coordination (UNDAC), continue to work with authorities to complete assessments and deliver assistance in affected areas [9]. The UN allocated US$4 million from the Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF) to support humanitarian operations in Grenada, Jamaica, and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines [5][9]. UNICEF is also jointly working with other agencies under the leadership of the UN RC/HC to prepare a joint appeal for Jamaica to support the response [10].

question: How has the Government of Jamaica coordinated with international organizations, such as the United Nations, to address the aftermath of Hurricane Beryl, and what specific support has been accepted?

Specific instances of coordination and support include:
*   On July 9, Minister Dana Morris Dixon from the Prime Minister's office briefed the International Development Partners Group, chaired by the UN Resident Coordinator (RC), on the situation and government relief efforts [2]. Minister Dixon expressed appreciation for the support offered by the international community and openness to work together [2].
*   The RC activated the United Nations Emergency Technical Team (UNETT) and reassured the Government of Jamaica that the UN was ready to support [2][4]. The UNETT, co-shared by UNICEF and WFP, continues to support the RCO lead in the joint UN response [1].

*   UNICEF is also jointly working with other agencies under the leadership of UN RCHC to prepare a joint appeal for Jamaica to support the response [3].
*   The UN allocated US$4 million from the Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF) to support humanitarian operations in Grenada, Jamaica, and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines [6][10].
*   Humanitarians, including teams from OCHA and UN Disaster Assessment and Coordination (UNDAC), continue to work with authorities in Jamaica to complete assessments and deliver assistance in affected areas [10].

question: What specific measures are being implemented to address the significant damage to livelihood infrastructure in the southern region of Jamaica following Hurricane Beryl?
retrieved_answer:
To address the significant damage to livelihood infrastructure in the southern region of Jamaica following Hurricane Beryl, several measures are being implemented:

*   **Damage Assessment and Recovery Planning:** The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) is deployed in affected areas of the Caribbean, including Jamaica, to advance rapid needs assessment and prepare proposals to restore production and livelihoods [1][2][5]. This includes damage and needs assessment using drones and satellite remote sensing, along with ground-level data collection through surveys and key informant interviews, all of which will guide response and recovery planning [1][2][5]. USAID also has disaster experts on the ground in Jamaica actively supporting damage assessments and coordination efforts [8].
*   **Direct Assistance and Financial Support:** Families in southern coastal areas, including Clarendon, Manchester, and St. Elizabeth, are in need of access to clean water, food, and reconstruction supplies for their homes, as well as psychological support [4][6]. In St Elizabeth, the Jamaica Public Service (JPS) Foundation and Food For The Poor (FFTP) Jamaica are providing care packages and access to charging stations [7]. Support to social protection systems is being implemented, including potential provision of food assistance to affected populations through existing government systems and modalities, and direct World Food Programme (WFP) assistance as required, utilizing cash-based transfers (CBT) and/or vouchers [13]. Investments in CBT assistance are expected to be complemented by a top-up of Jamaica's Caribbean Catastrophic Risk Insurance Facility (CCRIF) policy, which, if triggered, will direct a fixed percentage of a potential CCRIF payout towards providing cash transfers to impacted people via the country's social protection system [13].
*   **Infrastructure Restoration:** Hurricane Beryl most severely impacted Jamaica's southern coastal areas, causing damage to telecommunications, infrastructure, housing, public buildings, and healthcare facilities [4][6]. The Jamaica Public Service (JPS) and the National Water Commission (NWC) are working to restore utility services, including electricity and water, in affected communities [14].

title: Telecoms, climate change take centre stage at CANTO  content: In the wake of Hurricane Beryl's devastating impact on the Caribbean, the critical importance of robust telecommunications infrastructure and reliable data access was highlighted at the opening of CANTO's 39th Annual Trade Exhibition and Conference in Miami.Jamaica's Minister of Telecommunications Daryl Vaz, who delivered the feature address at Sunday's opening ceremony, just days after Beryl made landfall in Jamaica, emphasised the urgency of the region's climate crisis. "The Caribbean is on the front lines of the global climate crisis, facing significant and immediate impacts that threaten the region's environment, economy, and way of life," he said.He stressed the need for proactive and coordinated action: "Resilience and adaptive capacity are vital in the face of climate change. By embracing innovative solutions, fostering collaboration, and committing to sustainable practices, we can safeguard our islands for future generations. If we really want to survive and thrive, the time for talk is over and now is the time for action.

title: WFP continues support to communities affected by Cyclone Remal in Southern Bandgladesh  content: DHAKA  In support of the government-led response to Cyclone Remal, the United Nations World Food Programme WFP has been assisting affected communities through its cash-for-work programme to bolster their recovery and rebuilding efforts.Since June 25, nearly 6,000 households have participated in the programme led by WFP. The activities focus on repairing and rebuilding infrastructure such as embankments, roads and access routes that were badly damaged by the cyclone, utilising nature-based solutions like mud rebuilding and planting trees to prevent further erosion, whenever possible. Each family receives BDT 5,000 USD 43 for 10 days of work.Some 41,500 households in affected areas will be assisted through this programme, coupled with health, nutrition, and hygiene awareness messages.
